Literature Review: Single-atom catalysis (SAC) has emerged as a promising field due to its potential to enhance catalytic efficiency and selectivity by utilizing isolated metal atoms as active sites. The ability to observe these processes in real-time and at the atomic level is crucial for understanding the fundamental mechanisms that govern catalytic activity and stability. Dynamic in situ microscopy, particularly transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), has played a pivotal role in advancing this field by providing direct insights into the structural and chemical dynamics of catalysts under reaction conditions. Recent advancements in in situ TEM techniques have enabled researchers to visualize the formation, transformation, and deactivation of single-atom catalysts in real-time. For instance, Zheng et al. (2016) demonstrated the use of environmental TEM (ETEM) to study the dynamic behavior of platinum single atoms on titanium dioxide (TiO2) under reducing and oxidizing atmospheres. Their findings revealed that single platinum atoms could migrate and aggregate under certain conditions, leading to the formation of larger clusters and subsequent deactivation of the catalyst. This work highlighted the importance of controlling the local environment to maintain the single-atom dispersion and activity. Similarly, Li et al. (2018) utilized in situ STEM to investigate the structural evolution of single-atom iron catalysts supported on nitrogen-doped carbon during the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). They observed that the single iron atoms remained stable under the reaction conditions, which was attributed to the strong interaction between the metal atoms and the nitrogen-doped carbon support. This study underscored the significance of the support material in stabilizing single-atom catalysts and maintaining their catalytic performance. In addition to TEM and STEM, other in situ techniques such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and Raman spectroscopy have been employed to complement the microscopic observations. For example, Liu et al. (2019) combined in situ XAS with TEM to study the redox behavior of single-atom cobalt catalysts during the water-gas shift reaction. Their results showed that the single cobalt atoms underwent reversible oxidation and reduction cycles, which were essential for the catalytic activity. This integrated approach provided a comprehensive understanding of the electronic and structural changes occurring at the atomic level. The application of in situ microscopy in SAC has also led to the discovery of new catalytic phenomena. Wang et al. (2020) reported the observation of single-atom gold catalysts on ceria (CeO2) exhibiting enhanced activity for CO oxidation at low temperatures. Using in situ TEM, they found that the single gold atoms could dynamically interact with the ceria surface, leading to the formation of active oxygen species that facilitated the reaction. This study highlighted the role of the support material in modulating the catalytic properties of single-atom catalysts. Moreover, the development of advanced imaging techniques has further enhanced the capabilities of in situ microscopy. For instance, the use of aberration-corrected STEM has allowed for higher spatial resolution and better contrast, enabling the visualization of individual atoms and their immediate surroundings. Kim et al. (2021) utilized aberration-corrected STEM to study the dynamic behavior of single-atom palladium catalysts on graphene. They observed that the single palladium atoms could form transient clusters and then re-disperse under reaction conditions, which was crucial for maintaining the catalytic activity. This work demonstrated the potential of advanced imaging techniques in elucidating the complex dynamics of single-atom catalysts. The integration of machine learning algorithms with in situ microscopy has also opened new avenues for data analysis and interpretation. Zhang et al. (2022) developed a machine learning framework to automatically identify and track single-atom catalysts in large datasets generated from in situ TEM experiments. Their approach significantly reduced the time and effort required for manual analysis, allowing for more efficient and accurate characterization of catalytic processes. This integration of artificial intelligence with microscopy techniques is expected to accelerate the discovery and optimization of new catalysts. Despite the significant progress made in in situ microscopy for SAC, several challenges remain. One of the main challenges is the limited temporal and spatial resolution of current techniques, which can hinder the observation of fast and localized events. Additionally, the complexity of the reaction environments and the need for specialized equipment and expertise pose practical limitations. Future developments in instrumentation, data analysis, and theoretical modeling will be crucial for overcoming these challenges and further advancing the field. In conclusion, dynamic in situ microscopy has revolutionized the study of single-atom catalysis by providing unprecedented insights into the atomic-level processes that govern catalytic activity and stability. The continued development and integration of advanced microscopy techniques, complementary spectroscopic methods, and computational tools will be essential for achieving a deeper understanding of SAC and for designing more efficient and sustainable catalytic materials and processes.
